**Title:** *Rite and Vows to the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid*

**Preface to the Vows to the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid**

Vows are the aspirations of the perfected, and also the aspirations of all people. Each kneel and bow is the focus of the heart; the focus of the heart is the utmost of goodness. The goodness of human nature is like water flowing downward. If one does not correct what is not good, this is my sorrow. These vows are thus established for those who would be good—how could they be mere words of aspiration?

Gazing upward at heaven, one obtains the number twenty-five. Looking downward to earth, one obtains the number thirty. Combined, they yield fifty-five. It is by this number that the vow is fulfilled, for without sharing in the work of heaven and earth, how could this be achieved? The good person is the guiding principle of heaven and earth. If there is even a trace of deceit, arrogance, or negligence, this is not what I call a vow. How could such a one be spoken of in the same breath as the good?

The *Tradition* says: "Goodness has no constant master; it harmonizes with those who achieve unity." There is no other reason for this—beginning with it, ending with it, never halting halfway, this is to be perfectly good and perfectly beautiful.

Goodness is the foundation of fortune; fortune is the accumulation of goodness. Gao Ying of the Tang said: "Accumulate goodness to attain fortune; do not expend wealth to seek fortune." Since fortune can be sought without expending wealth, can those who do good be said to expend wealth? Seeing goodness, one should point it out; hearing goodness, one should proclaim it. All who share this aspiration should thus encourage one another, that we may be without shame before heaven and earth, and also without shame before the Venerable Lord. This, too, is the great vow of the Venerable Lord.

**Rite and Vows to the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid**

Today, with reverence, we burn precious incense and offer sincere devotion to:
The Great Immortal of the Nine Heavens’ Golden Gate, who illuminates the Dao and manifests virtue, whose numinous power is vast and whose aid is universal, who dwells in the pure and mysterious, the empty and subtle, whose compassion and kindness protect the state and shelter the people—the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace;
The Supreme Immortal of the Nine Heavens’ Jade Gate, who proclaims transformation and upholds the teaching, whose numinous radiance is far-reaching and whose aid is abundant, who is lofty and serene, empty and profound, whose wondrous responses are benevolent, who assists the state and protects the people—the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace;
And all the divine officials and immortals of the Palace of Numinous Aid, to whom we offer our common devotion.

We have heard that the manifest virtue of the spirits is called uprightness and wisdom. The common desire of people is for peace and ease, for wealth and honor. If sacrifices must bring blessings, then the rites must not be too simple. For over four hundred years, the temple offerings have flourished; the incense fire burns as brightly as ever. The stele inscriptions number a thousand characters, and their compositions may still be heard. Their illustrious and imperishable names, their awe-inspiring and lifelike righteousness—these have preserved the altars of the state and bestowed virtue upon the living.

The farmer labors in the fields, and there is celebration of millet, rice, and grain. The artisan refines his craft, meeting the standards of plumb line, compass, and square. The scholar establishes himself through loyalty and filial piety; the merchant profits through benevolence and righteousness. Those who seek marriage find harmony in family and home; those who pray for descendants beget sons and grandsons. Wind and rain nourish the people, fulfilling the wishes of all life. Clothing and food sustain us, granting the kindness of warmth and fullness. Bestowed upon the myriad things, all is fitting; arranged through the four seasons, all is in order.

Gazing up to them is like beholding Mount Tai or the Northern Dipper—their radiance is vast. They do not abandon us in the distance; when they manifest, it is as light, as stars and clouds contending in splendor, a joy to behold first. They are fitting recipients of great rites, that their numinous power may be proclaimed.

In the past, they received the honor of imperial bestowal; today, they bear the favor of heaven’s grace. Their rank has ascended to the Golden and Jade Gates; their names have advanced to the Great and Supreme Immortals. Their honorific titles are exalted, their majesty resplendent; their sacrifices endure for a hundred generations, their example rectifies the myriad spirits. They walk with the great creators, ever ancient yet never aging.

I, so-and-so, though my heart yearns for the Dao, my talent does not compare to others. I humbly extend my private gratitude and offer a small token of respect. Having prepared this solemn Dharma assembly, I presumptuously invoke the true wisdom of the Venerable Lord.

I pray that the jade phoenix may sing *jiujiu*, that the eight dragons may coil and glide, that clouds and rainbows may lead the way, that the gates may open at the sound of your approach. First, let Fenglong advance as your vanguard; then, let Feilian hasten as your retinue. Bestow your beauty with ease, repay with serene longevity. Offer cassia wine and peppered libations, orchid mats and magnolia feasts. Roam freely and linger, look back with care and affection.

My humble devotion is boundless; I await your presence with reverence.

There is the Venerable Lord’s original vow and divine incantation, which I shall now recite with care:

*Venerable Lord, Venerable Lord, Great Spirit of the Northern Dipper.*
*Heaven and earth praise your transformation; sun and moon shine together.*
*Below, you govern Fengdu; above, you attend the imperial court.*
*Upholding the true Dharma, you slay and vanquish evil spirits.*
*Your numinous title, Lingji, brings fortune to the myriad people.*
*Those who seek are answered, as echo follows sound.*
*Those who feel are moved, as shadow follows form.*
*Those who oppose me perish; those who follow me live.*
*Om, Radiant Numinous One, Radiant Numinous One, universally aid the living.*
*Qianyuan,亨利贞, swiftly, swiftly, as the law commands.*
*Venerable Lord of Numinous Aid, descend swiftly.*

The virtue of cherishing life pervades the hearts of the people. Preserve my two *qi*: the fiery *yang* and the watery *yin*. Dissolve disasters, cross over calamities, bring fortune to the good and misfortune to the licentious.
*Swiftly, swiftly, as the law commands.*

*Venerable Lord, Venerable Lord, born of the Northern Dipper.*
*Acting on heaven’s behalf, you transform; assisting the state, you save the people.*
*Transmitting the true Dharma, you slay and vanquish evil spirits.*
*Demon kings guard you; true qi abides forever.*
*Swiftly, swiftly, as the law commands.*

The divine incantations have now been fully proclaimed. We respectfully invite:
The Sacred Father, the Loyal and Martial True Lord of Aid and Brightness, Prince Qi;
The Sacred Mother, the Benevolent and Longevous, Kind and Virtuous Immortal Consort;
The Two Venerable Lords of Numinous Aid, the Two Immortal Consorts;
Their divine processions to descend and join the assembly of the perfected, to array themselves in ranks and pay homage.

Having completed the homage, each ascends to their Dharma throne. With reverence, we set out the offerings and burn incense.

*Ode to the Incense*

We humbly submit that bright virtue, when offered, surpasses the fragrance of millet and grain; those who cultivate goodness share their scent with orchids and angelicas. This incense—jade censers present auspicious omens, golden tripods manifest felicity. Dense and abundant, it coalesces into clouds of mist and vapor; warm and radiant, it steeps the cosmos in spring. When held aloft, messengers stand before us; when attended, youths stand behind. In rites with libations, we bow in reverence and make offerings. In rites without, the first cup of wine is presented, this incense accompanying the chalice—let the Dharma assembly focus their minds and make offerings with devotion.

*Incense Verse*
In the heavens, clouds sow their seeds;
A mighty wind scatters them across the four seas.
Deep within the dragon palace’s secrets,
Sea spirits offer them to the immortals.
Now, fervently kindled with sincerity,
Its mist ascends to the Purple Palace.
Penetrating the boundless void,
All prayers are fulfilled as wished.

*Response:* Together, we make offerings with one heart.

*Scattering flowers.*
From the censer’s depths, smoke arises.
*Scattering flowers through the forest.*
The incense of the effortless Dao and virtue.
*Scattering flowers to fill the Dharma realm.*
Offerings before the True Lords.

*Ode to the Water*

We humbly submit: though turbid waters may be offered to lords and nobles, only loyalty and sincerity form their true essence. The source-water flows ceaselessly day and night, yet we blush at the excess of our own reputation. This water—neither muddied nor dim—remains ever clear, ever pure. In heaven it becomes rain and dew, caught upon bronze pillars and golden stalks; on earth it turns to sweet springs, savored like jade nectar. The wise act without pretense, and the highest good, like water, contends with none.

Its current never fails to flow east, yet its source lies in the north.

*With ritual present:* We bow our heads in reverent offering.
*Without ritual:* The second cup of wine is presented, this incense accompanying the chalice—let the Dharma assembly focus their minds and make offerings with devotion.

*Ode to the Water*
In heaven the Silver River overflows,
its limpid depths reflecting the ten directions.
Transformed into rain and dew it descends,
bestowing grace across heaven and earth.
Moistening what is withered, nourishing all life,
its bounty revives the parched and sustains the myriad beings.
Pouring forth, it expresses our deepest sorrow—
body and mind wholly purified.

*Response:* Together, we make offerings with one heart.

*Scattering flowers.*
The source flows not from earthly veins.
*Scattering flowers through the forest.*
It waters all from the celestial river.
*Scattering flowers to fill the Dharma realm.*
Offerings before the True Lords.

*Ode to the Flowers*
We humbly submit: layered emerald leaves cast their shade upon the limpid isles; jade blossoms flourish, giving rise to spirit in the courts of abundance. These flowers—fragrant in their very essence, their hues unbound by fixed form. The red lotus of the pool may suddenly turn jade-green; the white peony can be dyed golden. In the Palace of Broad Cold, a single cassia branch trails its shadow beneath the autumn moon; within the Wu-ling grotto, a thousand peach trees smile in the breath of spring. Though we long to pour forth the devotion of sunflowers, we offer but the modest tribute of repeated veneration.

*With ritual present:* We bow our heads in reverent offering.
*Without ritual:* The final cup of wine is presented, this incense accompanying the chalice—let the Dharma assembly focus their minds and make offerings with devotion.

*Ode to the Flowers*
Rare blossoms of the Dark Garden flourish,
their roots spreading through the ten directions.
Standing tall for eight hundred years,
their fragrance lingers in the dusty world.
Resplendent in the realm of radiant light,
a cascade of jeweled petals rains down.
Gathering the purest essence,
we now rise to make our offering.

*Response:* Together, we make offerings with one heart.

*Scattering flowers through the forest.*

We humbly submit: in roaming the spirit through the Dao, one sees without seeing, hears without hearing. Abiding in the Dao with spirit, one gazes ahead—suddenly behind. Concealment has no end, and names are not forced upon it. Since the dawn of the Red Clarity, when celestial scriptures first descended, and the Heavenly Perfected took up their brushes, human culture began to flourish. The Emperor Shun received it before the Terrace of Pastoral Virtue; the Yellow Emperor transmitted it upon Mount Emei. Some obtained it at Gourd Valley, fulfilling the wish of King Helü; others descended upon Bell Mountain, completing the work of Yu the Great. Through the transmission of these scriptures and teachings, we sentient beings awaken to understanding.

May all sentient beings together attain the supreme Dao.

We perform the Triple Rite of Thanksgiving.

Disciples, with one heart, bow in reverence and thanks
To the True Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Golden Portal.
Disciples, with one heart, bow in reverence and thanks
To the True Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Jade Portal.
Disciples, with one heart, bow in reverence and thanks
To the Illustrious Father, True Lord of Supportive Brilliance.

The rites of thanksgiving complete,
Our repentance fully revealed,
We reverently follow the wondrous canon,
Daring to approach your numinous wisdom.
With sincere devotion, we lay bare our humble wishes.

We pray your sacred compassion deign to look upon us.

First, may the present emperor’s life be long,
His harmony and longevity matching Heaven’s—ten thousand, ten thousand springs.
Second, may ministers and officials enjoy rank and emolument,
Their blessings like wind and clouds—enduring for a thousand years of joy and prosperity.
Third, may scholars attain wealth and honor,
Their names rising to Heaven’s court as dukes and ministers.
Fourth, may farmers diligently till the soil,
From this year onward, year after year, rejoicing in triple harvests.
Fifth, may all artisans perfect their crafts,
Awaiting summons to the Golden Gate to hear the jade decree.
Sixth, may the path to wealth be great,
Comparable to the lords of a thousand households.
Seventh, may wind and rain be timely,
All under Heaven celebrating universal peace.
Eighth, may incense and offerings ever flourish,
The temple’s majesty and numinous power enduring for a thousand years.
Ninth, may the Nine Heavens bestow their mandate,
Jade pendants chiming as we approach the Purple Court.
Tenth, may all faithful and good in the ten directions
Turn to the Three Treasures with utmost devotion.

The above hymn of praise and rites now complete,
The merit and virtue fulfilled.

All in the ritual assembly, each with reverence, speak again:
We have heard that with trembling caution,
We shame ourselves for our repeated offenses.
In awe of your radiant majesty,
We behold your numinous presence close at hand.
Grateful in heart, we bow and declare:
Your virtue shines forth—manifest and luminous,
Your merit extends boundlessly, aiding all.
You are the bridge across the sea of suffering,
The sun and moon guiding the lost.

Today, we reverently follow the sacred decree,
Conducting this ritual of gratitude and prayer for blessings.
We face your true wisdom, proclaiming your wondrous example.
With the devotion of triple ablutions and triple incense,
We dare to offer our gaze and our reverence.
May the impartial gods see our sincerity,
Washing away the sins of past kalpas and this life,
That we may plant the seeds of present and future karma.
With beginning and end, without evil or song,
What can be grasped, the foolish cannot reach;
Yet the gods transform, and the people are rightly guided.
When merit is complete and deeds perfected,
We may ascend to the Jade Chamber and Cinnabar Terrace.
When qi abides and spirit is upright,
We may open the brocade pouch of the Purple Sun.
May all faithful men and women attain long life,
Countless generations of ancestors be delivered.
Extending even to the departed in darkness,
All may return to the vast Mahayana.
For these supreme causes, we earnestly invoke:
The Heaven-Blessed Honored Lord of the Nine Heavens,
The Ten-Thousand-Fortunes-Protecting-Body Honored Lord,
The Heaven-Invoked-Fruit-Attaining Honored Lord.
Together: Inconceivable merit and virtue.

The *Ritual Text of Offering and Prayer to the Numinous Aid True Lord* is now complete.

chunks.original_text: 洪恩灵济真君礼愿文 经名：洪恩灵济真君礼愿文。 撰人不详。 一卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞玄部威仪类。 洪恩灵济真君愿文序 愿者，真人之愿也，亦人之所愿也。 一跪一拜，心之专也。 心之专，善之至也。 人性之善，犹水就下也。 不善不改，是吾忧也。 此愿所以为善者设是，岂徒愿文乎哉。 仰观於天，得数二十五。 俯法於地，得数三十。 合而言，得数五十五。 盖因此数得以成其愿，若非与天地同功，安能至此。 善人天地之纪也。 苟有一毫矫伪慢怠之意，非吾之所谓愿也。 其可与善者同日语耶？ 《传》曰：善无常主，协于克一。 此无他，始於是，终於是，不以半涂而自画，斯为尽善而尽美也。 善者，福之基。 福者，善之积。 唐高郢有言：积善以致福，不费财以求福，福既可以不费财而求，则为善者可曰费财乎。 见善以相示，闻善以相告，凡吾同志，当以此自相勉励。 庶无愧於天地，亦无愧於真君，此又真君之大愿也。 洪恩灵济真君礼愿文 以今恭焚宝香，虔诚供养： 九天金阙明道达德大仙显灵溥济清微洞玄冲虚妙感慈惠护国庇民洪恩真君， 九天玉阙宣化扶教上仙昭灵博济高明弘静冲湛妙应仁惠辅国佑民洪恩真君， 灵济宫中神仙诸灵官普同供养。 恭闻神之显德，曰正直而曰聪明。 人所常情，欲安逸而顾富贵。 祭之必受福也，礼其无太简乎。 庙食余四百年，香火如彼其盛。 碑铭凡一千字，文章可得而闻。 昭昭不朽之名，凛凛如生之义。 功全社稷，德在生灵。 农力於耕，有黍稷稻粱之庆。 工精其艺，合准绳规矩之程。 士以忠孝立身，商以仁义为利。 问婚者，宜家宜室。 祈嗣者，生子生孙。 风风人，雨雨人，均遂生成之愿。 衣衣我，食食我，俱沾温饱之仁。 施之万物得其宜，措之四时得其序。 仰之如太山北斗，厥光大矣。 不我遐遗，现则为景，星庆云争，先睹之以为快乐。 宜受大礼，以宣厥灵。 昔膺勅额之荣，今荷天恩之宠。 位既登於金阙玉阙，名乃进於大仙上仙。 徽号褒崇，威仪赫奕，祀延百世，表正万神。 与大造以为徒，长上古而不老。 伏念某心虽慕道，才不如人。 少伸昭谢之私，略致涓埃之敬。 具严法会，干冒真聪。 伏愿呜玉鸾兮啾啾，驾八龙兮蜿蜿，率云霓兮来迓，令闻阖兮开关，先使．丰隆兮前驱，后使飞廉兮奔属，委厥美兮从容，赛将澹兮寿光，桂酒奠兮椒浆，蕙肴蒸兮兰籍，逍遥兮容与，低回兮顾怀。 某下情无任勤拳，颙俟之至所； 有真君本愿神咒，谨当持诵： 真君真君，北斗大神。 天地赞化，日月并明。 下主酆都，上朝帝庭。 奉行正法，斩伐邪精。 灵济徽号，福及万民。 有求必应，如谷随声。 有感必通，如影随形。 逆我者死，顺我者生。 唵昭灵昭灵，普济生灵。 乾元亨利贞，急急如律令。 灵济真君，速降来临。 好生之德，洽于民心。 存吾二气，火阳水阴。 消灾度厄，福善祸淫。 急急如律令。 真君真君，北斗降生。 代天行化，助国救民。 流传正法，斩伐邪精。 魔王拱卫，真气常存。 急急如律令。 向来神咒，已具敷宣。 奉请： 圣父齐王忠武翊亮真君， 圣母仁寿淑善仙妃， 灵济二位真君、二位仙妃，法驾降临预会众真，列班朝礼。 朝礼既周，各升法座。 虔诚设拜上香。 叹香
chunks.translated_text:
**Rite and Vows to the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid**

**Title:** *Rite and Vows to the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid*
**Author:** Unknown
**Volume:** One
**Source Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongxuan* Section, *Weiyi* (Ritual Propriety) Category

---

**Preface to the Vows to the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid**

Vows are the aspirations of the perfected, and also the aspirations of all people. Each kneel and bow is the focus of the heart; the focus of the heart is the utmost of goodness. The goodness of human nature is like water flowing downward. If one does not correct what is not good, this is my sorrow. These vows are thus established for those who would be good—how could they be mere words of aspiration?

Gazing upward at heaven, one obtains the number twenty-five. Looking downward to earth, one obtains the number thirty. Combined, they yield fifty-five. It is by this number that the vow is fulfilled, for without sharing in the work of heaven and earth, how could this be achieved? The good person is the guiding principle of heaven and earth. If there is even a trace of deceit, arrogance, or negligence, this is not what I call a vow. How could such a one be spoken of in the same breath as the good?

The *Tradition* says: "Goodness has no constant master; it harmonizes with those who achieve unity." There is no other reason for this—beginning with it, ending with it, never halting halfway, this is to be perfectly good and perfectly beautiful.

Goodness is the foundation of fortune; fortune is the accumulation of goodness. Gao Ying of the Tang said: "Accumulate goodness to attain fortune; do not expend wealth to seek fortune." Since fortune can be sought without expending wealth, can those who do good be said to expend wealth? Seeing goodness, one should point it out; hearing goodness, one should proclaim it. All who share this aspiration should thus encourage one another, that we may be without shame before heaven and earth, and also without shame before the Venerable Lord. This, too, is the great vow of the Venerable Lord.

---

**Rite and Vows to the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid**

Today, with reverence, we burn precious incense and offer sincere devotion to:
The Great Immortal of the Nine Heavens’ Golden Gate, who illuminates the Dao and manifests virtue, whose numinous power is vast and whose aid is universal, who dwells in the pure and mysterious, the empty and subtle, whose compassion and kindness protect the state and shelter the people—the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace;
The Supreme Immortal of the Nine Heavens’ Jade Gate, who proclaims transformation and upholds the teaching, whose numinous radiance is far-reaching and whose aid is abundant, who is lofty and serene, empty and profound, whose wondrous responses are benevolent, who assists the state and protects the people—the Venerable Lord of Vast Grace;
And all the divine officials and immortals of the Palace of Numinous Aid, to whom we offer our common devotion.

We have heard that the manifest virtue of the spirits is called uprightness and wisdom. The common desire of people is for peace and ease, for wealth and honor. If sacrifices must bring blessings, then the rites must not be too simple. For over four hundred years, the temple offerings have flourished; the incense fire burns as brightly as ever. The stele inscriptions number a thousand characters, and their compositions may still be heard. Their illustrious and imperishable names, their awe-inspiring and lifelike righteousness—these have preserved the altars of the state and bestowed virtue upon the living.

The farmer labors in the fields, and there is celebration of millet, rice, and grain. The artisan refines his craft, meeting the standards of plumb line, compass, and square. The scholar establishes himself through loyalty and filial piety; the merchant profits through benevolence and righteousness. Those who seek marriage find harmony in family and home; those who pray for descendants beget sons and grandsons. Wind and rain nourish the people, fulfilling the wishes of all life. Clothing and food sustain us, granting the kindness of warmth and fullness. Bestowed upon the myriad things, all is fitting; arranged through the four seasons, all is in order.

Gazing up to them is like beholding Mount Tai or the Northern Dipper—their radiance is vast. They do not abandon us in the distance; when they manifest, it is as light, as stars and clouds contending in splendor, a joy to behold first. They are fitting recipients of great rites, that their numinous power may be proclaimed.

In the past, they received the honor of imperial bestowal; today, they bear the favor of heaven’s grace. Their rank has ascended to the Golden and Jade Gates; their names have advanced to the Great and Supreme Immortals. Their honorific titles are exalted, their majesty resplendent; their sacrifices endure for a hundred generations, their example rectifies the myriad spirits. They walk with the great creators, ever ancient yet never aging.

I, so-and-so, though my heart yearns for the Dao, my talent does not compare to others. I humbly extend my private gratitude and offer a small token of respect. Having prepared this solemn Dharma assembly, I presumptuously invoke the true wisdom of the Venerable Lord.

I pray that the jade phoenix may sing *jiujiu*, that the eight dragons may coil and glide, that clouds and rainbows may lead the way, that the gates may open at the sound of your approach. First, let Fenglong advance as your vanguard; then, let Feilian hasten as your retinue. Bestow your beauty with ease, repay with serene longevity. Offer cassia wine and peppered libations, orchid mats and magnolia feasts. Roam freely and linger, look back with care and affection.

My humble devotion is boundless; I await your presence with reverence.

There is the Venerable Lord’s original vow and divine incantation, which I shall now recite with care:

*Venerable Lord, Venerable Lord, Great Spirit of the Northern Dipper.*
*Heaven and earth praise your transformation; sun and moon shine together.*
*Below, you govern Fengdu; above, you attend the imperial court.*
*Upholding the true Dharma, you slay and vanquish evil spirits.*
*Your numinous title, Lingji, brings fortune to the myriad people.*
*Those who seek are answered, as echo follows sound.*
*Those who feel are moved, as shadow follows form.*
*Those who oppose me perish; those who follow me live.*
*Om, Radiant Numinous One, Radiant Numinous One, universally aid the living.*
*Qianyuan,亨利贞, swiftly, swiftly, as the law commands.*
*Venerable Lord of Numinous Aid, descend swiftly.*

The virtue of cherishing life pervades the hearts of the people. Preserve my two *qi*: the fiery *yang* and the watery *yin*. Dissolve disasters, cross over calamities, bring fortune to the good and misfortune to the licentious.
*Swiftly, swiftly, as the law commands.*

*Venerable Lord, Venerable Lord, born of the Northern Dipper.*
*Acting on heaven’s behalf, you transform; assisting the state, you save the people.*
*Transmitting the true Dharma, you slay and vanquish evil spirits.*
*Demon kings guard you; true qi abides forever.*
*Swiftly, swiftly, as the law commands.*

The divine incantations have now been fully proclaimed. We respectfully invite:
The Sacred Father, the Loyal and Martial True Lord of Aid and Brightness, Prince Qi;
The Sacred Mother, the Benevolent and Longevous, Kind and Virtuous Immortal Consort;
The Two Venerable Lords of Numinous Aid, the Two Immortal Consorts;
Their divine processions to descend and join the assembly of the perfected, to array themselves in ranks and pay homage.

Having completed the homage, each ascends to their Dharma throne. With reverence, we set out the offerings and burn incense.

*Ode to the Incense*

We humbly submit: though turbid waters may be offered to lords and nobles, only loyalty and sincerity form their true essence. The source-water flows ceaselessly day and night, yet we blush at the excess of our own reputation. This water—neither muddied nor dim—remains ever clear, ever pure. In heaven it becomes rain and dew, caught upon bronze pillars and golden stalks; on earth it turns to sweet springs, savored like jade nectar. The wise act without pretense, and the highest good, like water, contends with none.

Its current never fails to flow east, yet its source lies in the north.

*With ritual present:* We bow our heads in reverent offering.
*Without ritual:* The second cup of wine is presented, this incense accompanying the chalice—let the Dharma assembly focus their minds and make offerings with devotion.

*Ode to the Water*
In heaven the Silver River overflows,
its limpid depths reflecting the ten directions.
Transformed into rain and dew it descends,
bestowing grace across heaven and earth.
Moistening what is withered, nourishing all life,
its bounty revives the parched and sustains the myriad beings.
Pouring forth, it expresses our deepest sorrow—
body and mind wholly purified.

*Response:* Together, we make offerings with one heart.

*Scattering flowers.*
The source flows not from earthly veins.
*Scattering flowers through the forest.*
It waters all from the celestial river.
*Scattering flowers to fill the Dharma realm.*
Offerings before the True Lords.

*Ode to the Flowers*
We humbly submit: layered emerald leaves cast their shade upon the limpid isles; jade blossoms flourish, giving rise to spirit in the courts of abundance. Sons and grandsons abound in blessings.

With devoted heart we bow and take refuge,
In the Dragon-Headed Temple’s courtyard, the Sacred Realm of Ao Peak,
Lightning flashes, clouds rise high,
Heaven speaks not, yet its voice thunders in wrath,
The earth’s bounty relies on rain and dew to nurture life,
Divine mechanisms operate in the unfathomable,
Wondrous transformations turn in the formless,
Grace descends upon the nine regions,
Blessings extend to all living beings—
Most sacred, most numinous, transforming and changing—
Lord Thunder, Mother Lightning, Earl Wind, Master Rain,
The Illustrious Dragon Kings of this temple,
The Earth Gods of the Five Directions,
The Rain-Bringing Dragon Spirits, and all others.

Dragons ride the clouds, their power assured,
Their voices shake the thunder for ten thousand miles.
The world’s people long for timely rain,
At once their fortunes rise, their horns emerge—

With devoted heart we bow and take refuge,
In the Sacred Realm of Ao Peak, the Dragon-Headed Temple’s courtyard,
Most sacred, most numinous, to the left and right,
Some present their jesting arts,
Others excel in the arts of the *guanlu*,
Those who oversee the kitchen wield the eight delicacies,
Those who direct music harmonize the six pitches,
The Sixteen Guardians of the Army, all born with the talents of generals,
The Three Hundred Cavalry, each destined for enfeoffment,
Their majesty and numen manifest,
Their images fierce and vivid—
Most sacred, most numinous, stern and protective—
All the numinous powers of the entire hall.

For their labors in stabilizing the state and enacting laws for the people,
Their incense and karmic ties enshrine them in the temple.
The renown of generals and ministers endures through the ages,
Their images praised for a thousand years, likened to the qilin.

The rites complete, each rises and kneels in devotion,
Sincerely repenting with reverence.
With devoted heart, body, spirit, and life, we take refuge
In the Nine Heavens’ True Lord of Numinous Aid and all the majestic immortals of the hall.

We humbly beseech the sacred compassion,
To bestow vast blessings and descend abundant grace.
Through this day’s solemn fast and devotion,
We sincerely take refuge and repent.
We have heard that misfortune and fortune have no fixed gate,
Only summoned by one’s own actions;
Omens of good and ill follow like shadows.
Good serves as the tally of evil,
Evil as the proof of good.
For those who do good,
The Five Phases support them, the Overseer of Fate befriends them.
For those who do evil,
Malevolent qi overwhelms them, baleful stars shine upon them.

chunks.original_text: 虽天网之难逃，在人心之知觉。 今辰伏念，一切众生，归心向道，至诚感神。 躬礼真聪，首陈自责，爰从曩劫，迨至今生。 耻过作非，去顺效逆，变情徇势，挟诈抵巇。 以幽阴诡侧而行其奸，以毒酷残忍而肆其害。 颠倒梦想，昏迷乎利名智之场。 杀盗邪淫，沉汨於贪嗔痴之境。 大则欺於天地，幽则负於神明。 咨暑怨寒，呵风骂雨。 或对星辰而便利，或对日月而裸裎。 或指虹霓，或盟山海。 破坏庙社，触秽道场。 不知身心口意之非，不安士农工贾之分。 不崇三宝，不习五常。 为人谋而不忠，与朋交而不信。 事亲非孝，背主忘恩。 为富不仁，重财不义。 谓祭无益，谓暴无伤。 谓敬不足行，谓言不足畏。 犯上作乱，好勇疾贫，斥陷忠良，侵凌孤弱。 欺公灭私，薄人厚己。 教唆词讼，结构冤雠。 侮慢自贤，傲虐自作。 不明乎善，不诚乎身。 小弁作而或父子之恩亏，常鄂废而或兄弟之情缺。 国俗败而兴谷风之刺，骨肉怨而歌角弓之诗。 既知罪恶之贯盈，恭对慈悲而忏悔。 人谁无过，过而能改，每怀战战栗栗之忧。 神无常享，享于克诚，少致切切拳拳之悃。 伏愿至仁孚佑，大道垂怜，赦其已往之愆，锡以方来之祉。 群方胥庆，率土蒙恩。 当今之日太平，灾不生，祸不作。 诸福之物毕至，老者壮，少者强。 久钦灵德之威光，用作济民之事业。 臣等至心稽首，再拜礼谢灵济 二位真君。 举三礼谢 弟子一心稽首礼谢 九天金阙真君。 弟子一心稽首礼谢 九天玉阙真君。 弟子一心稽首礼谢 圣父翊亮真君。 礼谢已周，忏情毕露，恭依妙典，干冒威聪。 谨按丹诚，披陈素愿。 伏愿圣慈俯赐鉴临。 一愿当今皇帝寿，和寿与天齐万万春。 二愿臣僚资禄位，和风云千载庆嘉亨。 三愿儒冠多富贵，和名登天府作公卿。 四愿农民勤稼穑，和自今岁岁喜三登。 五愿百工精技艺，和待诏金门听玉音。 六愿生财有大道，和千户封君可比伦。 七愿风调并雨顺，和普天率土贺升平。 八愿香火常隆盛，和千年庙貌显威灵。 九愿九天加锡命，和玉佩锵趋拜紫宸。 十愿十方诸信善，和皈依三宝各虔诚。 上来恭礼赞文，功德已周。 道场众等人，各虔诚再伸启白： 伏闻兢兢业业，自惭童渎之再三。 赫赫明明，恭睹威颜之咫尺。 铭心知感，稽首扬言。 德之着者，曰显灵昭灵，功可推而为溥济博济。 津梁众苦，日月群迷。 今辰钦奉圣旨，修设酬恩祈福道场。 臣等恭对真聪，宣扬妙范。 少伸三沐三熏之敬，敢殚一瞻一礼之恭。 神听无私，情由可鉴。 用涤曩劫今生之罪业，愿作见在未来之果因。 有始有终，无恶无歌。 知可及，愚不可及； 神化之，民使宜之。 行满功圆，可以进於玉室丹台之上。 气存神正，可以开於紫阳云锦之囊。 信女善男，咸得长生。 亿曾万祖，皆即受度。 遍及幽冥之异类，尽归缥缈之大乘。 为上因缘，志心称念： 九天锡庆天尊，万福护身天尊，请天证果天尊。 和：不可思议功德。 洪恩灵济真君礼愿文竟
chunks.translated_text:
Though Heaven’s net is hard to escape,
Yet all lies in the awakening of the human heart.

This day, we prostrate in reflection:
All sentient beings turn their hearts toward the Dao,
Their utmost sincerity moving the gods.
We bow in reverence before the True and All-Hearing,
First confessing our faults,
From past kalpas to this present life.
Ashamed of wrongs, we have acted perversely,
Turned from right to follow wrong,
Altered our nature to chase power,
Embraced deceit to exploit flaws.
In darkness and secrecy, we schemed with cunning,
In cruelty and savagery, we wrought harm.
Deluded by dreams, we wandered lost
In the fields of profit, fame, and cunning.
Killing, stealing, lust, and deceit—
We sank into the mire of greed, wrath, and delusion.
In great matters, we deceived Heaven and Earth;
In secret, we betrayed the gods.
We cursed the heat, railed against the cold,
Scolded the wind, reviled the rain.
Before the stars, we sought advantage;
Before the sun and moon, we bared ourselves.
We pointed at rainbows, swore by mountains and seas,
Defiled temples and shrines, polluted sacred precincts.
Unmindful of the wrongs of body, heart, mouth, and intent,
Unsettled in the roles of scholar, farmer, artisan, merchant.
We honored not the Three Treasures, nor practiced the Five Constants.
In serving others, we were disloyal;
In friendship, untrustworthy.
Toward parents, unfilial;
Toward lords, ungrateful.
Wealthy yet unkind,
Greedy yet unjust.
We called sacrifice futile,
Violence harmless.
Deemed reverence unworthy,
Words unworthy of fear.
We rebelled against superiors, stirred chaos,
Loved violence, hated poverty,
Slandered the loyal, bullied the weak.
We served public ends for private gain,
Exalted ourselves at others’ expense.
We incited lawsuits, sowed enmity,
Arrogant in self-regard, cruel in self-will.
Unclear in goodness, insincere in conduct.
Small resentments eroded the bond of father and son,
Neglect dissolved the love of brothers.
When customs decayed, we sang the *Gu Feng* in reproach;
When kin turned to hatred, we chanted the *Jiao Gong* in lament.
Now, knowing our sins have filled the measure,
We humbly face the merciful and repent.

Who among us is without fault?
Yet faults, once mended, bring trembling fear.
The gods accept no fixed offerings,
But respond to utmost sincerity—
Thus we offer our earnest, reverent devotion.

We pray the Most Benevolent grant protection,
The Great Dao show compassion,
Forgive our past transgressions,
Bestow future blessings.
Let all regions rejoice,
All lands receive grace.
May this day bring great peace,
Disasters cease, misfortunes end.
May every blessing arrive,
The old grow strong, the young vigorous.
Long have we revered the awe-inspiring power of your virtue,
Now we dedicate ourselves to works that aid the people.

With utmost sincerity, we bow our heads,
Twice prostrating to give thanks to the Two True Lords of Numinous Aid.
We perform the Triple Rite of Thanksgiving.

Disciples, with one heart, bow in reverence and thanks
To the True Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Golden Portal.
Disciples, with one heart, bow in reverence and thanks
To the True Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Jade Portal.
Disciples, with one heart, bow in reverence and thanks
To the Illustrious Father, True Lord of Supportive Brilliance.

The rites of thanksgiving complete,
Our repentance fully revealed,
We reverently follow the wondrous canon,
Daring to approach your numinous wisdom.
With sincere devotion, we lay bare our humble wishes.

We pray your sacred compassion deign to look upon us.

First, may the present emperor’s life be long,
His harmony and longevity matching Heaven’s—ten thousand, ten thousand springs.
Second, may ministers and officials enjoy rank and emolument,
Their blessings like wind and clouds—enduring for a thousand years of joy and prosperity.
Third, may scholars attain wealth and honor,
Their names rising to Heaven’s court as dukes and ministers.
Fourth, may farmers diligently till the soil,
From this year onward, year after year, rejoicing in triple harvests.
Fifth, may all artisans perfect their crafts,
Awaiting summons to the Golden Gate to hear the jade decree.
Sixth, may the path to wealth be great,
Comparable to the lords of a thousand households.
Seventh, may wind and rain be timely,
All under Heaven celebrating universal peace.
Eighth, may incense and offerings ever flourish,
The temple’s majesty and numinous power enduring for a thousand years.
Ninth, may the Nine Heavens bestow their mandate,
Jade pendants chiming as we approach the Purple Court.
Tenth, may all faithful and good in the ten directions
Turn to the Three Treasures with utmost devotion.

The above hymn of praise and rites now complete,
The merit and virtue fulfilled.

All in the ritual assembly, each with reverence, speak again:
We have heard that with trembling caution,
We shame ourselves for our repeated offenses.
In awe of your radiant majesty,
We behold your numinous presence close at hand.
Grateful in heart, we bow and declare:
Your virtue shines forth—manifest and luminous,
Your merit extends boundlessly, aiding all.
You are the bridge across the sea of suffering,
The sun and moon guiding the lost.

Today, we reverently follow the sacred decree,
Conducting this ritual of gratitude and prayer for blessings.
We face your true wisdom, proclaiming your wondrous example.
With the devotion of triple ablutions and triple incense,
We dare to offer our gaze and our reverence.
May the impartial gods see our sincerity,
Washing away the sins of past kalpas and this life,
That we may plant the seeds of present and future karma.
With beginning and end, without evil or song,
What can be grasped, the foolish cannot reach;
Yet the gods transform, and the people are rightly guided.
When merit is complete and deeds perfected,
We may ascend to the Jade Chamber and Cinnabar Terrace.
When qi abides and spirit is upright,
We may open the brocade pouch of the Purple Sun.
May all faithful men and women attain long life,
Countless generations of ancestors be delivered.
Extending even to the departed in darkness,
All may return to the vast Mahayana.
For these supreme causes, we earnestly invoke:
The Heaven-Blessed Honored Lord of the Nine Heavens,
The Ten-Thousand-Fortunes-Protecting-Body Honored Lord,
The Heaven-Invoked-Fruit-Attaining Honored Lord.
Together: Inconceivable merit and virtue.

The *Ritual Text of Offering and Prayer to the Numinous Aid True Lord* is now complete.
